#Text=Hannah Twynnoy
#Text=Hannah Twynnoy ( 1669/70-1703 ) is the first person to have been killed by a tiger in Britain , as attested to by a formal contemporary source .

#Text=Twynnoy , by repute and according to a memorial plaque now lost , was an early 18th-century barmaid working in The White Lion public house in the centre of the English market town of Malmesbury in Wiltshire .
#Text=All that remains from the time , to corroborate the narrative of her death , is her gravestone , in a corner of the churchyard of Malmesbury Abbey .
#Text=Gravestone
#Text=Her gravestone records her name and death at the age of 33 on 23 October 1703 , with a relatively long , evocative poem which reads :
#Text=In bloom of Life
#Text=She 's snatchd from hence , She had not room
#Text=To make defence ; For Tyger fierce Took Life away .
#Text=And here she lies
#Text=In a bed of Clay , Until the Resurrection Day . [ 1 ]
#Text=Plaque recorded in a local history
#Text=To the memory of Hannah Twynnoy .

#Text=She was a servant of the White Lion Inn where there was an exhibition of wild beasts , and amongst the rest a very fierce tiger which she imprudently took pleasure in teasing , not withstanding the repeated remonstrance of its keeper .

#Text=One day whilst amusing herself with this dangerous diversion the enraged animal by an extraordinary effort drew out the staple , sprang towards the unhappy girl , caught hold of her gown and tore her to pieces .
#Text=Recorded by the Athelstan Museum [ 2 ]

#Text=Historian John Bowen has found a local history with a more detailed account of the death as , it states , placed on a plaque on the wall of the parish church in Hullavington , a village 5 miles ( 8km ) from Malmesbury .

#Text=The plaque ( see box for wording ) that appeared to have been installed soon after her death , in the first years of the 18th century , was recorded in the Victorian period by a local historian and may since have been sold , melted down or stolen .
#Text=Oral history

#Text=The common thread of such stories by word of mouth from generation to generation , matches exactly the plaque , almost always with less formal wording , stating that Hannah Twynnoy was a barmaid working at a pub called the White Lion in Malmesbury ( 8 Gloucester Street , later converted to a private house ) in 1703 when a menagerie arrived to set up in the pub 's large rear yard .
#Text=Among the animals there was included a tiger , which Hannah was warned against upsetting .
#Text=She liked bothering the animal until one day it got tired of it and mauled her .
#Text=Hannah did not survive .
#Text=Unsolved aspects of the death
#Text=Wealth or pity ?
#Text=Poetic epitaphs on gravestones were popular at the turn of the 18th century , but generally only for the wealthy and celebrated . [ 1 ]

#Text=A gravestone and a plot in the churchyard of Malmesbury Abbey for any woman , who could not have been a priest or a priest 's wife , would have been costly , even without engaging the services of a poet .
#Text=The identity of the patron who paid for her tombstone and plot remains a mystery , although they may have been donated by the church and vestry .
#Text=Family
#Text=Her connection with the village of Hullavington , which kept family records at this time , seems anomalous .
#Text=Her sole connection comes from a later local historian giving the wording and location of a plaque .
#Text=The parish registers and Bishops transcripts for Malmesbury contain no entry , between 1635 and 1700 , for anyone named Twynnoy .
#Text=However , the Malmsbury parish register for October 24 , 1703 , ( burials ) , states : Hannah Twynney kild by a Tygre at ye White Lyon . [ 3 ]
#Text=Enduring legacy
#Text=In 1993 a new residential road in Malmesbury was named ' Twynnoy Close ' . [ 4 ]

#Text=In 2003 , on the 300th anniversary of the death , a ceremony was carried out at the grave when every schoolgirl in the town , younger than 11 and named Hannah , placed a flower on the grave . [ 5 ]
#Text=Twynnoy was featured in the ' Stupid Deaths ' segment of the CBBC programme Horrible Histories ( Series 4 , Episode 6 ) .
#Text=Notes and references
